title: Alexander Cummings (territorial governor)
added: Cummings had a bitter feud with the pro-state Secretary of the Colorado Territory, [[Samuel Hitt Elbert]].  Upon his arrival in Colorado, Cummings was not satisfied with the quality and location of the territorial offices and accused Elbert of deliberatively selecting them to inconvenience him and the territorial government.  When Cummings moved the office, he took the Great Seal of the Territory which was used to affix public documents.  Elbert demanded the return of the seal since it was his official duty to use the seal.  The feud escalated to Cummings' superior, U.S. Secretary of State [[William H. Seward]] and prompted the resignation of Elbert.{{sfn|Hanchett|1957|pp=87-89}}

title: Alexander Cummings (territorial governor)

Cummings was not satisfied with the quality and location of the territorial offices and accused Elbert of deliberatively selecting them to inconvenience him and the territorial government.  Cummingsselecteda betterofficeand whenhemoved,took the Great Seal of the Territory which was used to affix public documents.  Elbert demanded the return of the seal since it was his official duty to use the seal.  The feud escalated to Cummings' superior, U.S. Secretary of State [[William H. Seward]] and prompted the resignation of Elbert.{{sfn|Hanchett|1957|pp=87-89}}

title: Alexander Cummings (territorial governor)
added: Cummings had a bitter feud with the pro-state Secretary of the Colorado Territory, [[Samuel Hitt Elbert]]. Cummings was not satisfied with the quality and location of the territorial offices and accused Elbert of deliberatively selecting them to inconvenience him and the territorial government.  Cummings selected a better office and when he moved, took the Great Seal of the Territory which was used to affix public documents.  Elbert demanded the return of the seal since it was his official duty to use the seal.Cummings accused Elbert of attempting to use the seal to illegally reverse the 1864 vote to reject Colorado statehood.The feud escalated to Cummings' superior, U.S. Secretary of State [[William H. Seward]] and prompted the resignation of Elbert.{{sfn|Hanchett|1957|pp=87-89}}

title: Alexander Cummings (territorial governor)
added: Cummings had a bitter feud with the pro-state Secretary of the Colorado Territory, [[Samuel Hitt Elbert]]. Cummings was not satisfied with the quality and location of the territorial offices and accused Elbert of deliberatively selecting them to inconvenience him and the territorial government.  Cummings selected a better office and when he moved, took the Great Seal of the Territory which was used to affix public documents.  Elbert demanded the return of the seal since it was his official duty to use the seal.  Cummings accused Elbert of attempting to illegally reverse the 1864 vote to reject Colorado statehoodand break up the territorial government. Pro statehood newspapers such as the [[Rocky Mountain News]] took up Elbert's cause and published negative stories of Cummings record with the War Department. The feud escalated to Cummings' superior, U.S. Secretary of State [[William H. Seward]] and prompted the resignation of Elbert.{{sfn|Hanchett|1957|pp=87-89}}

Cummings selected a better office and when he moved, took the Great Seal of the Territory which was used to affix public documents.  Elbert demanded the return of the seal since it was his official duty to use the seal.  Cummings accused Elbert of attemptingto use the sealto illegally reverse the 1864 vote to reject Colorado statehood and break up the territorial government. Pro statehood newspapers such as the [[Rocky Mountain News]] took up Elbert's cause and published negative stories of Cummings record with the War Department. The feud escalated to Cummings' superior, U.S. Secretary of State [[William H. Seward]] and prompted the resignation of Elbert.{{sfn|Hanchett|1957|pp=87-89}}

Elbert demanded the return of the seal since it was his official duty to use the seal.  Cummings accused Elbert of attempting to use the seal to illegally reverse the 1864 vote to reject Colorado statehood and break up the territorial government. title: Alexander Cummings (territorial governor)
added: Cummings had a bitter feud withtheterritorial government second in command, pro-state Secretary of the Colorado Territory, [[Samuel Hitt Elbert]]. Cummings was not satisfied with the quality and location of the territorial offices and accused Elbert of deliberatively selecting them to inconvenience him and the territorial government.  Cummings selected a better office and when he moved, took the Great Seal of the Territory which was used to affix public documents.  Elbert demanded the return of the seal since it was his official duty to use the seal.  Cummings accused Elbert of attempting to use the seal to illegally reverse the 1864 vote to reject Colorado statehood and break up the territorial government. Pro statehood newspapers such as the [[Rocky Mountain News]] took up Elbert's cause and published negative stories of Cummings record with the War Department. The feud escalated to Cummings' superior, U.S. Secretary of State [[William H. Seward]] and prompted the resignation of Elbert.{{sfn|Hanchett|1957|pp=87-89}}

title: Alexander Cummings (territorial governor)
added: In January 1867, the Colorado territorial legislature passed a law continuing the practice of forbidding African Americans from serving on juries.  Cummings vetoed the bill but the legislature overrode the veto.{{sfn|Hanchett|1957|p=100}}

title: Alexander Cummings (territorial governor)
added: In January 1867, the Colorado territorial legislature passed a law forbidding African Americans from serving on juries.  Cummings vetoed the bill but the legislature overrode the veto.{{sfn|Hanchett|1957|p=100}}
